MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Radon Gas.

Qst.Quest: the proposals, if any, submitted for consideration in the forthcoming budget for the scheme of grant aid for the remediation of radon gas in households.

if her attention has been drawn to the fact that between 250 and 300 people die each year as a consequence of the ingestion of radon gas in their homes; the plans, if any, she has to introduce a radon remediation grants scheme for householders; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of Public Enterprise (Mr. Jacob)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 27 and 59 together.

I am aware that international epidemiological research has shown a link between long-term exposure to radon and lung cancer and that radon may be implicated in approximately 10% of total lung cancer deaths. No funds are being provided in the provisional Estimates for my Department for the year 2000 for the introduction of a grant scheme.

MainHeading.P: The Radiological Protection Institute of Ireland has received the necessary funding to survey the extent of the radon problem in Ireland and to create public awareness of the problems associated with high radon levels. Following the completion of the RPII's national survey this year, we now have a complete picture of those locations designated by the RPII as high radon areas. Along with the RPII, I have been urging households in these areas to contact the RPII with a view to having the radon levels in their homes assessed.

Qst.Quest: the changes, if any, she proposes in the methodology used to allocate mobile phone licences; if the procedures to date have been satisfactory; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.P: The licensing of mobile telephone operators is a function of the Director of Telecommunications Regulation and the procedures applied by the director in exercising that function are a matter for the director subject to general legal requirements and to certain requirements laid down in the European Communities (Telecommunications Licences) Regulations, 1998 (S.I. No. 96 of 1998), including the requirement that the licensing procedures be open, non-discriminatory and transparent. I have no proposals to change these requirements at this time.
As the licensing of the third mobile phone operation is subject to legal proceedings, it would not be appropriate to comment on the procedures applied in that case.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Telecommunications Services.

Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, she has to review any aspect of the legislation relating to the Office of the Director of Telecommunications Regulation with particular reference to the representations and appeal procedures.

Speaker.P: The question of appeals against decisions made by the Director of Telecommunications Regulation is one of a number of issues relating to the effectiveness of the telecommunications regulatory framework which my Department is currently examining. This work follows an announcement which I made last April of my intention to have legislative proposals prepared to provide the director with a firm basis for the regulation of the sector well into the next millennium. It is my intention to bring the necessary legislative proposals before Government as soon as practicable.

MainHeading.P: The issue of appeals against the decisions of sector-specific regulators also comes within the scope of the consultative process on regulation which I have recently initiated. That process is intended to lead to a discussion document which will address a range of issues relevant to the current and future regulatory environment in Ireland.

Qst.Quest: the steps, if any, she is taking to ensure that there will be a comprehensive integrated ticketing system for commuters between the different CIÉ companies.

Speaker.P: I support the concept of integrated ticketing. Work is currently under way by a committee chaired by my Department to make recommendations on an appropriate system for Dublin, taking account of the costs and benefits involved. I expect its report with recommendations within the next few months.

It will be necessary to ensure that any system will be flexible enough to allow for the participation of all the CIE companies and other public transport operators, including a possible private operator of the light rail system under a public private partnership.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Telecom Éireann Flotation.

Qst.Quest: if her attention has been drawn to complaints made by Telecom Éireann share applicants who did not receive share certificates or nominee account statements for several weeks after 14 July 1999 when share dealings commenced; her views on whether the delay in delivering those certificates and statements resulted in loss to persons who had intended trading in the shares as soon as was practicable to do so; the nature and scale of the problem; the reason for the delay; if those responsible for this delay owe any duty either to share purchasers or to her as seller of the shares; if those responsible will indemnify shareholders for any losses suffered; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.P: I am aware that a number of applicants did not receive share certificates or nominee statements for some time after 14 July 1999. The delays arose for a variety of reasons, including transmission delays in the postal system and applications that had either insufficient address details or required extra processing.

About 570,000 people applied for shares in the retail offer. Given the sheer volume of applications it is inevitable that some difficulties may arise in a certain proportion of individual cases. I understand that the number of applicants who did not receive their shares for some time after 14 July was about 0.5% of the total number of applicants. Where difficulties arose, my Department endeavoured to do everything possible to assist the applicants involved within the terms of the retail offer.

MainHeading.P: Procedures are in place for applicants who feel they have been unfairly treated during the retail offer process. A review group comprised of Department officials and advisers was set up immediately following the flotation to adjudicate on cases where applicants feel their application for shares in Telecom Éireann was not processed equitably in accordance with the terms of the offer. Applicants can also contact Computershare, the registrars to Eircom, if they have a query.
If the Deputy has any particular case that he would like to refer to the review group, I would be pleased to arrange for it to be reviewed.

The sale of shares was conducted in accordance with the terms of the retail offer and the question of my Department compensating purchasers who have availed of that offer does not arise. In any case, the movements in the share price since the IPO date are a matter for the international financial markets.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Post Office Network.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. O'Keeffe Mr. J. O'Keeffe
Qst.Quest: the work and progress made and reports furnished by the interdepartmental working group established to oversee progress in the development of the post office network.

Speaker.P: Following the Government decision on 27 May last that the post office network should be further developed as a one-stop-shop through the provision of an enhanced range of facilities in post offices, I established an interdepartmental working group, representative of the Department of the Taoiseach together with the Department of the Environment and Local Government and of my own Department, to explore all possibilities in this regard with a view to speedy implementation of initiatives wherever feasible. Possibilities being examined by the group include, inter alia, the payment of ESB bills, motor taxation renewal demands and publicly-available Internet access.

As a first step in the direction of enhancing the range of services available in post offices, last July An Post and Aer Lingus rolled out a facility whereby cash payments for that airline's tickets may be made at post offices.

MainHeading.P: I have been updated regularly on the work of the interdepartmental group. The Deputy will appreciate that, as its remit covers a wide area involving a number of Government Departments and other bodies, it is important to undertake consultation, where necessary, with all concerned parties. As its work is of an ongoing nature, the working group will continue to report to me on a regular basis as new possibilities for enhancing the range of services available in post offices are identified and further specific initiatives are taken.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Telecommunications Services.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. Bruton Mr. J. Bruton
Qst.Quest: the areas in respect of which no proposals for projects supporting the development of advanced telecommunications networks and services to be co-funded by the European Union have been received; and the steps, if any, she will take to ensure that these areas in respect of which no commercial interest in providing services was expressed will not lose out in terms of regional development.

Speaker.P: The Deputy will be aware that the provision of advanced telecommunications infrastructure is primarily a matter for operators in the newly liberalised telecommunications market.

Recognising that in certain regions of the country competition alone will not provide the required advanced telecommunications infrastructural investment, I engaged a consortium of consultants led by Norcontel (Ireland) Limited to manage three calls for projects supporting the development of advanced telecommunications networks and services which might be co-funded by INTERREG and European Regional Development Fund European Union funding.

The nine successful projects from the first and second calls were announced on 5 July 1999, details of which are set out in the following tabular statement. These entail 23 million euros of EU moneys leveraging a further 32 million euros of private sector investment. This investment will result in the provision of advanced telecommunications infrastructure to over 120 towns in 21 counties around the country.

The third call for proposals closed on 16 August 1999 and four projects seeking 3.6 million euros of EU co-funding have been approved subject to contract. It is intended to announce the result of this call shortly. All of these projects are to be completed by 31 December 2000.

No proposals were received for certain parts of the Border, midlands, mid east and south east regions. My Department is currently reviewing advanced telecommunications investment needs in the context of the next national development plan. The needs of all regions of the country will be considered in this review, especially those for which proposals did not emerge in previous rounds.
